posts.message:
This article was a godsend. Thank you so much for clarifying these concepts. Some additional thoughts:

I have been playing around with this last couple days. What CDK calls the RemovalPolicy is more-or-less the same as CloudFormation DeletionPolicy for the resource. However, setting the RemovalPolicy (for example: to RETAIN) on the CDK construct results now seems to set both UpdateReplacePolicy as well as DeletionPolicy on the CloudFormation resource. If both of these are set, then we generate snapshots both when (1) we delete the stack, as well as (2) when deploying an update that requires the resource be replaced.
posts.raw_message:

posts.message:
I am someone who does not have a good grounding in unicode or python. I am hoping you can help me in a problem I am having using your script. When I run it, I get frequent errors. They result from collisions between regular English and unicode versions of actor's names. For instance, 'Zsa Zsa Gabor' and 'Zsa Zsa Gábor' entries in my Kodi DB result in a collision when trying to add the entries to the MariaDB database. The unicode version gets converted to the regular English version and then the script hits an error because it's trying to add a row with a duplicate key. This happens quite frequently with LatinX names but also others. Any idea how to correct this?

windom

posts.message: Is there a way to get OctoPrint to finish printing the current layer, pause after the layer is complete, save the progress of the print to the SD Card, then shutdown after the extruder heater drops below 50 degs? Idea being that it continues printing until 50% of the UPS's battery is used up, then it completes the current layer which makes for a nice stopping point. Then, once power is restored, the printer and OctoPrint can be booted back up and progress can be resumed from where it left off.

posts.message:
Well, it wasn't so much a "switch". I'd used MythTV about 10-15 years ago, when my Internet connection was relatively slow and I had cable. I had a MythTV setup with 2 cable boxes and 2 tuners, and multiple frontends.

About three years ago I switched from Xfinity to AT&T Fiber as it became available to me (amazing ISP, by the way) and in the process I dropped TV service and went to Internet only.

The decision to use Kodi was largely based on (1) not having TV, therefore having no use for a PVR, which seems like the bulk of MythTV's functionality, (2) Kodi seems to be more widely used these days, especially on Raspberry Pi hardware, and (3) I have two co-workers who use Kodi, so I know I can always get advice if needed.

posts.raw_message:
Parameters:
  DBName:
    Default: wordpress
    Description: The WordPress database name
    Type: String
    MinLength: '1'
    MaxLength: '64'
    AllowedPattern: '[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*'
    ConstraintDescription: must begin with a letter and contain only alphanumeric characters.
  DBSnapshotIdentifier:
    Description: ' The RDS MySQL snapshot name to restore to the new DB instance.'
    Type: String
    Default: ''
Conditions:
  UseDbSnapshot:
    'Fn::Not':
      - 'Fn::Equals':
          - Ref: DBSnapshotIdentifier
          - ''
Resources:
  DBInstance:
    Type: 'AWS::RDS::DBInstance'
    Properties:
      DBName:
        'Fn::If':
          - UseDbSnapshot
          - Ref: 'AWS::NoValue'
          - Ref: DBName
      Engine: MySQL
      MasterUsername:
        Ref: DBUsername
      DBInstanceClass:
        Ref: DBClass
      DBSecurityGroups:
        - Ref: DBSecurityGroup
      DBSubnetGroupName:
        Ref: DBSubnetGroup
      AllocatedStorage:
        Ref: DBAllocatedStorage
      MasterUserPassword:
        Ref: DBPassword
      DBSnapshotIdentifier:
        'Fn::If':
          - UseDbSnapshot
          - Ref: DBSnapshotIdentifier
          - Ref: 'AWS::NoValue'
      MultiAZ: true
    DeletionPolicy: Snapshot
  WebServerGroup:
    Type: 'AWS::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup'
    Properties:
      LaunchConfigurationName:
        Ref: LaunchConfig
    UpdatePolicy:
      AutoScalingRollingUpdate:
        MinInstancesInService: '1'
        MaxBatchSize: '1'
        WaitOnResourceSignals: 'true'
        PauseTime: PT10M
      AutoScalingScheduledAction:
        IgnoreUnmodifiedGroupSizeProperties: true
    CreationPolicy:
      ResourceSignal:
        Timeout: PT10M
        Count: '2'
  LaunchConfig:
    Type: 'AWS::AutoScaling::LaunchConfiguration'
    Metadata:
      'AWS::CloudFormation::Init':
        config:
          files:
            /opt/wordpress/cloudformation_db.php:
              content:
                'Fn::Join':
                  - ''
                  - - |
                      <?php
                    - 'define(''DB_NAME'',          '''
                    - Ref: DBName
                    - |
                      ');
                    - 'define(''DB_USER'',          '''
                    - Ref: DBUsername
                    - |
                      ');
                    - 'define(''DB_PASSWORD'',      '''
                    - Ref: DBPassword
                    - |
                      ');
                    - 'define(''DB_HOST'',          '''
                    - 'Fn::GetAtt':
                        - DBInstance
                        - Endpoint.Address
                    - |
                      ');

posts.message:
Douglas,
Unfortunately this blog post seems to be the only thing left of either that console or the truck. The truck was totaled in a highway accident in 2010 and the console went with the salvage vehicle, since I wasn't going to get another of the same year. Wherever the plans and dimensions for the console were, they haven't survived me moving four times in the 12 years since this post.

I know that I mentioned drawing up plans in CAD, but wherever they are (if anywhere), I can't find them.

The best I can really do is explain to you, from memory, how I came up with the dimensions in the first place, which should make sense with the pictures above:

* The width was almost exactly the distance between the two armrests. This was a mistake, because I didn't account for the thickness of the carpeting that covered it, and I ended up never making the planned lid for the console. In reality, it should be narrow enough to fit between the arm rests taking into account the thickness of the carpet on both sides, and allowing a little extra space so it's not rubbing on them. I also ended up having to build up the sides of the middle and front portions quite a bit, in order to fit standard console panels (however wide they are, I don't remember). Looking back, I could've made the whole thing a couple inches narrower and it would've worked much better with the seats and also not had as wide an area on either side of the equipment panels.
* The height of the rear box was supposed to be just below the bottom of the arm rests.
* The height of the front "hump" by the dash was designed so that the cupholders in the dash could still pull out, and so that I could *barely* access the in-dash 12v outlet (not that I needed to; I ended up putting a 4x 12v outlet box on the side of the console)
* To come up with the dimensions and angles for the bottom (note there's a large flat part, a rise near the front of the bottom, and also a dip down near the back of the bottom) I removed the factory console and then used various lengths of wood / straight edge pressed down against the floor to figure out what the actual profile of the transmission hump was. Once I had a pretty good idea, I transferred the profile to the edge of a single piece of plywood, pressed it down against the trans hump, and adjusted as needed until I had something that fit well. I think I may have also used various types of angle and contour finders when coming up with the profile.
* The overall shape of the front profile - tip up for the trans hump, vertical flat portion, tip back to fit under the dash, horizontal flat at the top to fit under the pull-out cup holders - is largely based on me leaning into the truck with a piece of foam board and a utility knife, and just shaving off pieces until I found something that fit nicely.
* The depth of the front and middle sections was mostly based on the depth of the equipment that I wanted to mount in it, plus the wires/cables coming out the backs. I knew, for example, that my switch box would fit in the middle area but my scanner (and future radio that was added) had to go in the angled front area with more clearance behind the panels.

My biggest regret with this whole build was the carpeting that I used. Pretty much everyone who saw this said something along the lines of "that looks great, why'd you ruin it with that awful carpeting?". While the sample square that I got seemed like it was pretty close to the factory original, the actual carpet that I received was *much* thicker with a *much* higher pile. It looked really weird and out of place. It also had a really heavy backing, which made it essentially impossible to bend around the corners of the plywood. I'm pretty sure that the thinner material they make for subwoofer enclosures would have worked out much better.

-Jason

posts.message:
I just wanted to thank you for your short blog post. It was indeed extremely useful for me. I puchased a 4-port router from ebay, link below:

https://www.ebay.com.au/itm...

Unfortunately, when I tried booting from my USB key with VyOS 1.1.8 it also was very unhappy and wouldn't boot. It kept dropping me at a "busybox" ash shell. My device also had the AMI BIOS. Once I found your post, and navigated to the south bridge -> USB Configuration settings and disabled XHCI and enabled EHCI on the USB ports, it booted perfectly.

If anyone finds this useful, the "manual" (if you can call it that), says the manufacturer website is http://www.xcympc.com/ and my device is a model X33. Unfortunately, nowhere except your post explicitly described how to reconfigure the BIOS for VyOS to boot successfully.

Thanks once again!

posts.message:
Shawn,
I'd be happy to help, but keep in mind that I'm using what are now *way* outdated ZoneMinder versions, so my experience might not be that helpful for modern ZM versions. I'll also say that I was relatively shocked at how poor the performance is... so I might not have any real tips for you.

My main ZM machine (also running HomeAssistant, so not completely dedicated) is a refurbished HP Elite 8200 small form factor desktop; i7 quad core 3.8GHz with 16GB memory. I've dropped all my cameras to stream at 10fps and I have ZM set to capture at 12fps. I've got one old camera at 1280x960 and 8 at 1920x1080, and the system *barely* keeps up. It's fine if someone is walking past one of the cameras, but if it's very windy or raining and all the cameras have motion at once, it drops frames all over the place. When relatively idle, ZM reports the machine as having a load of somewhere between 1 and 2, so that's pretty nice and quiet, but that can jump up to 6-8 with lots of motion on the cameras, and that's no good for anything video-related. This machine is running ZM 1.30.4.

My other ZM machine is running 1.32.3 and is a similar refurbished desktop with a slightly faster quad-core i7. It's currently running 2 cameras at 2304x1296 at 20fps and 1 camera at 1920x1080 10fps. That's about the most it can handle; it sits around a load average of 1.4-1.7 when idle, and (more or less, if the system were literally not doing anything other than ZM) anything beyond that will start dropping frames.

I arrived at my current setup through some relatively extensive tuning of motion detection and frame rates to figure out the most I can get out of the hardware I have.

It's also definitely worth noting that the ZONE part of zoneminder, the motion detection zones, contribute a lot to resource usage. The fewer and smaller zones you have, the better performance will be. I also needed to do a fair amount of tuning the various per-camera buffer sizes (warmup, pre-event, post-event, etc.) to get something that works well on my system.

I hope this helps. But the bottom line (IMO) is that ZoneMinder is very flexible, very full-featured, and easily (if rather complexly) configured... at the expense of performance. I'm sure that if the motion detection zones had to be provided as bitmap masks instead of built point-and-click in a GUI, and the whole system used configuration files for everything instead of the web UI and database, the performance would be a bit better (at the expense of being vastly less user-friendly).

I'll also say that I've heard there have been some major improvements in versions of ZM newer than the ones I'm running... even including crazy things like capturing video natively instead of capturing frames... so perhaps the performance has improved as well.

posts.message:
Chaitanya,

Two points:

1. I wrote this post in August 2016 - three and a half years ago. AWS has certainly added many features since then. While there might be a more concise way to do this today (or in the near future), I can't find any quicker or simpler way to get webhook contents in to an SQS queue.
2. This is really about the idea of reusable, composable pieces that started with The Unix Philosophy and has been carried on through a lot of Free / Open Source Software. The main idea here is that this project provides an infinitely reusable component to handle the [webhook -> lambda -> sqs] portion of things. You can then use SQS as a loose coupling between multiple or many instances of this project, and multiple or many instances of different downstream consumers that implement the [sqs -> consumer with business logic] portion of things.

-Jason

The main idea here is that this project provides an infinitely reusable component to handle the [webhook -> lambda -> sqs] portion of things. You can then use SQS as a loose coupling between multiple or many instances of this project, and multiple or many instances of different downstream consumers that implement the [sqs -> consumer with business logic] portion of things.

-Jason

posts.message:
Hi s,

I ended up going with ZoneMinder (there's an overview of what I currently have at https://blog.jasonantman.co... and all of my related posts with the "surveillance" tag are listed at https://blog.jasonantman.co... ). I did a native installation of ZoneMinder on Debain, no Docker, and haven't been having any CPU issues with it despite pushing it pretty hard.

I haven't revisited Docker since I got all of that working. I have a friend who's using a ZoneMinder docker image ( https://hub.docker.com/r/dl... ) and says it works well, but I haven't tried it for myself yet.

I've been running on Intel-based hardware (x86_64) both because my needs are pretty high (I'm currently running HomeAssistant and ZoneMinder with 9 cameras, mostly 1920x1080 at 10fps, on the same machine) and because I just wanted the ease of knowing that I can find pre-built packages for pretty much anything I want.

Best of luck!
Jason

posts.message:
Hey Jason, thank you very much for quick reply.

Well, after I wrote my message, I spent several hours researching what device would fit my requirements. At the same time I really did not want to buy something size and price of Mac Mini or similar - as I said, I needed to keep costs and space consumed by the solution at minimum.

Finally I pulled the plug and ordered Nvidia Jetson Nano kit. It is just 2x the price of PI 4 and based on specs:
https://www.nvidia.com/en-s...

it should have sufficient power not only do decode of two 720P streams sent from remote cameras, but do object classification/face detection and more.

My question to you would be - how much work do you think it would require to adapt your solution to Jetson Nano and plus integrated learning/face recognition in addition? My minimum required first step would be just motion detection and close to real time notification using messaging services. Face/object detection should be the next step.

Or, if asking the question more broadly - knowing what you know now, if starting from the scratch, what would do leave as is and what would you change?

Thanks again

posts.message:
Irakli,

The relatively powerful system and GPU are really only required for (1) object recognition, and (2) because I'm doing motion detection on LOTS of video... right now, 9 cameras each doing 10 frames per second at 1920x1080 32-bit color.

Looking at the specifications of the Pi 4, I'd guess that it would be more than enough to handle motion detection only, for two low resolution video streams. Given the low cost of the Pi 4, and the high odds that if you did end up needing something larger, you could probably sell the Pi 4, I'd suggest giving that a try.

-Jason

posts.message:
Hello Jason,

Thank you for writing up your experiences on this subject - give me quite an info.

I am at the beginning of the journey of surveillance/detection/notification. My goal is simple - keep costs at minimum while designing a system which has following components:
- two PI zeros acting as network cameras sending lower resolution (800x600) stream each to the central server
- central server without a camera which does stream processing from two remote PI zeros and does motion detection and alerting via email/telegram/whatsapp

I was thinking using either PI 3+ or 4 as a central server for such task but based what I understand from your writings, it seems that much more serious machine with a GPU is required. Is this correct? I did check Motion/MotionEye/MotionEyeOS but I've discovered significant lag with notification - email notification came 30-40 seconds after the event and there is no integration with messaging services.

I am not planning to do any object/face recognition at this moment, also motion detection needs to be done during the day only.

So... do you recommend not to spend more my time on this and just go and gram second-hand compact server with GPU or are there any alternatives?

Thanks

posts.message:
Very well said, and I do agree that people should use what works for them. I'll admit that once I get something working for myself and invest some time in learning and customizing it, I very rarely take the time to seriously investigate alternatives - let alone switch - unless something very major changes.

Definitely agreed regarding the security of IP cameras. All of mine are on a separate VLAN with Internet traffic in and out blocked, and the single computer that I have ZoneMinder running on is the only other thing that can access the camera network.

It sounds like from an integration standpoint, Xeoma can do pretty much everything that I'm currently doing with ZoneMinder - sending motion/recording events to an external tool, allowing an external trigger for recording, and renaming/labeling events.

It *does* seem like ZoneMinder is under somewhat active development recently, and has had some considerable improvements. The latest version now supports recording directly to video instead of still frames, experimental support for recording audio as well if desired, and has a slightly less ancient-looking interface. It's certainly still not on par with decent proprietary software (the user interface vs functionality disparity that's plagued a lot of F/OSS).

Likewise, thanks for the discussion.

Regarding Disqus... I suppose it's about time that I look into alternatives. When I moved this blog from a real web server to a static site hosted on GitHub Pages back in 2014, Disqus was the only functional option I could find that required no server-side anything (i.e. works with GitHub Pages), didn't have a cost to me, would allow me to use an API to import comments from my old WordPress installation, and dealt with spam acceptably. I'd certainly be open to alternatives.

posts.message:
I share the exact same sentiment but until free software can compete with paid it's just not worth it for me. The security aspects are concerning but you can easily get around those. I have Xeoma internet access blocked (going in or out) and only access it via my VPN outside my network (my vpn credentials are.. very long).

If you are worried about security from Xeoma you would be even more afraid of the security aspects of cameras themselves. IP cameras are notorious to being hacked. All the cameras on my network are blocked from communicating with anything except my home server. I'll probably go even further in the future and set them up on their own second network only connected to my server.

Also I would argue that Xeoma is almost as flexible as ZoneMinder (and even more in some cases) and much easier to use due to using block-style programming similar to node-red. I've been able to integrate motion events into Home Assistant and even setup some cool automations like not recording inside my house when either my wife or me are home. I've also been able to setup motion lights out in front of my house using Hue lights and Xeoma's motion events (https://skylar.tech/send-mo... for more information). Lastly I use my Hue outdoor motion sensors for triggering my cameras (only if it's dark though because the heat of the sun triggers these all day long) and it labels the archive videos with what trigger them.

I really hope the open-source alternatives get better but I haven't seen much progress over the last 4 years. Because the security problems I had were easy to get around I am fine with my current setup.

Thanks for the response and the article. I am always keeping my eyes open to new things.

EDIT: I am also surprised you have that opinion on open source software and security yet you are using Disqus which is terrible with privacy. They are supposedly even worse then FB when it comes to mining data. https://replyable.com/2017/...

posts.message:
I've been using ZoneMinder for the past year or so now. I can't say that I'm terribly *impressed* with it, or that I'm exactly happy with the streaming. But beyond my normal feelings about Free Software, which are pretty strong, there's just no way I'd allow proprietary software to record cameras inside my home.

There are lots of benefits to Free Software in general - both the moral, if you share that view, and the practical that I can make ZoneMinder do things most proprietary software couldn't. But when it comes to something as privacy-sensitive as recording video from cameras inside my home, my confidence that ZoneMinder is used by many, many other people, has easily-available source code, and doesn't contain any backdoors or send any of the video to a remote system, is more important to me than pretty much all of the other features.

posts.message:
Ted,

Glad that's working well for you. Raspberry Pis generally use SD cards for their OS/boot storage, and can handle cards up to 32 or 64 GB. They also have USB 2.0 as well as wired Ethernet. Depending on your actual storage needs in terms of image size, reliability, and amount of frames stored, you could use an external disk via USB 2, write directly to some sort of network-attached storage, or - my plan at the time - store the most recent images on the SD card and then have a daemon that synchronizes them to network storage and cleans up old images.

That being said, I ended up going with a full desktop computer to handle the system that I ended up developing (and am currently using), as described at: https://blog.jasonantman.co...

-Jason

posts.message:
According to the documentation on ALB access logs, the access logs are written to S3 as gzipped files with the ".log.gz" extension. In the docs on the Logstash S3 input plugin:

Files ending in .gz are handled as gzip’ed files.

So you shouldn't have to do anything, it should automatically detect the ".gz" extension on the files and decompress them as it reads them.

posts.message:
Thanks for using AppDaemon and for explaining your use of it - I'm always happy to see what other people do with it!

As part of the upcoming 4.0 release, I am revisiting the whole area of logging and have made a few changes:

- Each App has it's own child logger
- Formatting is now done natively with formats
- For a while now, the underlying logger object has been available albeit as a global object until now, and now the individual child logger objects are available

What this means is that:

- It is now possible to set an individual app to a different logging level with a simple API call
- You will also be able to set app log levels individually via the new admin interface
- Changing the format string for an app ought to have more predictable results.

I'd be interested in your feedback on these changes an also any other ideas you have. If you want to take these changes for spin they will be in the dev build soon.

posts.message:
Great Article…. I was impressed with the level of detail with success and failures and to the point...

So here is my story on my CCTV solution, Strong in Windows and new to Linux but really wanted to learn more about so in my voyage looking for a solution I could say I’ve tested a few, some with success and many with failures. iSpy I was able to get running quick and easy but it kept giving me the blue screen of death. Tried multiple physical computers and virtual under VMware even with every OS available to me from XP to Server 2008. All the same.. So I began look in the Linux world, again being new most of the documentation lacked the necessary details needed to the products working (Open Source is not for the amateurs).

So I did focus on zoneminder, after a few failures I found a set of instructions under Ubuntu 16.04, https://zoneminder.readthed...
Presto, it’s working… I had a mix of cameras from all over, I had them all blocked at the Firewall because we know what security risks are on IoT… So I thought maybe I can re-flash them using openip.cam, well being a Linux amateur and maybe some ADHD it did not take long to kick that to the curb.

To keep this tread short, here is where I am today… Been playing with Raspberry Pi’s for almost a year working different projects. A month ago I started working the Pi Cameras… Played most with raspivid and then VLC, both worked with limitations… Last weekend loaded motioneye and I was impressed with the simplicity of the install and some of the options available, so I decided to push the limits and loaded 4 pi cams and used a 5th B+ as the host for them all, well it started choking a bit… So I now use motioneye as the camera load (turn off everything possible), resolution 1280x768 @ 30FPS and use zoneminder for the server portion.

For me with 7 camera’s loaded with motion eye and zoneminder (2% load) on a physical box DMZ’ed I’m pleased with the progress of my CCTV solution. Additionally I use the zmNinja for a mobile app and again very pleased.
My main concerns are security (does my camera have a back channel, not now), camera cost and the proprietary software like only works with our mobile app.

4 more Pi’s on the way, hope to be here today… So I’m running Pi Zero W, Camera’s vary from 5MP with and without IR to learn more on the environments they will support. I have 2 8MP Pi camera’s on the way. My Point, Pi Zero costs 35 for the kit, and about 25 for the camera, so for 50 bucks I get pretty good quality.

This weekend I’m getting a 3 head LED security light, going to remove the center light and replace with a Pi Zero… So let’s see how this comes out. You can see I’m a Pi Fan even more now.
I would like to know other Pi experiences and if there is something I can do better.

Go check out Xeoma. It costs money but nothing else on the market beats it and runs on linux. I tried iSpy but hated that the machine the software runs on has to be the machine you view the cameras from (and even if you used their web access it was terribly slow). I run Xeoma in a docker on my home server which doesn't have a monitor, keyboard, or mouse. I am able to remotely configure everything through their app on any device (you get full access to all settings from the android app even).

I also tried Zoneminder. I personally thought it was garbage. Web interfaces (through chrome, firefox, etc) just can't compete with a native app. I love how Xeoma actually keeps the interface the same no matter what device you are viewing on.

If you are actually serious about security cameras I recommend you checkout Xeoma. It costs money but I have found that all the free alternatives are lacking compared to the paid software.

Xeoma runs in a docker on my home server (which is headless). I can connect to it from any device (PC, laptop, tablet, etc). You can also run it on a raspberry pi (as the server). I have motion areas setup on my outdoor cameras to trigger outside lights when motion is detected.

I've been using Xeoma for years now and still can't find software that comes close (hence why I am looking at this article just to see what the options are currently).

Anyone else feel the need to tell Comcast / Xfinity / Time Warner / whoever they are now, that if they cannot provide a detail of how my data is used, then they shouldn't be able to charge me for overages? Phone companies must be able to catalog every GB of data used on your phone, along with text messages, and phone calls, how come Comcast doesn't have to do this and provide us usage data? Weekly, Daily, hourly, (maybe even more?)... to me this should be something required by the FCC if they're going to charge for overages. There should be some kind of audit available to us.

How do I know they aren't simply padding their usage numbers each day or month or week for me? I've been trying to track this in a similar manual process, and some days I'm using 40gb in a single day and others 5gb with no real obvious changes to my overall usage and I can't put my finger on where all my data goes every month. Back in June and July I was over by almost 250gb, then in august all of a sudden I only used 600gb total... what changed? I have no idea! Was someone skimming my internet? How can I know? When will someone file a class action suit against them? This is total garbage!

posts.message:
gpsd is polled at a set interval in GpsLogger.run() ( code: https://github.com/jantman/... ). That method blinks one of the LEDs (LED1 in the code) according to:

* if no fix, blink 3 times quickly (0.1s on, 0.1s off)
* if 2D fix, blink twice (0.5s on, 0.25s off)
* if 3D fix, blink once (0.5s on, 0.25s off)

Parsing the fix itself happens in the GpsResponse class (code: https://github.com/jantman/... ) that I wrote, which decodes the gpsd JSON response into a class the represents the data, and has some convenience attributes for things like the type of fix.

posts.raw_message:
gpsd is polled at a set interval in GpsLogger.run() ( code: https://github.com/jantman/pizero-gpslog/blob/master/pizero_gpslog/runner.py#L78 ). That method blinks one of the LEDs (LED1 in the code) according to:

* if no fix, blink 3 times quickly (0.1s on, 0.1s off)
* if 2D fix, blink twice (0.5s on, 0.25s off)
* if 3D fix, blink once (0.5s on, 0.25s off)

Parsing the fix itself happens in the GpsResponse class (code: https://github.com/jantman/pizero-gpslog/blob/master/pizero_gpslog/gpsd.py ) that I wrote, which decodes the gpsd JSON response into a class the represents the data, and has some convenience attributes for things like the type of fix.

The Antenna Farm is great if you don't get defective items. Here's what I submitted to BBB.

On 9/1 I purchased a Laird Technologies ETRA1440 antenna. It arrived defective. I emailed the company about advance-sending a replacement, because I couldn't find return/exchange information anywhere on the site. I received this email, which I found quite rude: "Just click on "returns" at the bottom left side of any of our website pages." I emailed a screen shot showing there was no such link. I then received this email: "Use a home PC" So, I sent a photo of my computer monitor also not displaying such a link. I then received this email: "Sir it's just a defective antenna for a hobby... not a defective child. I'm sorry you are experiencing such problems." I've already placed over $300 in orders from this company. This is horrible customer service. All I asked for was an advance-shipment replacement, not terse, rude responses from a customer who has already spent $300 and was about to spend $200 more. I'm taking my business elsewhere, and so should anyone else thinking of purchasing from this place.

posts.message:
What a great idea! To mitigate coupling the surge through the power wiring, you might try running the power connection for the cable modem through a ferrite core multiple times, or at least into a multiple-loop coil to add some impedance on the power path. A lightning strike seems to have a fairly steep rise time and thus, a high-frequency component, so a little bit of inductance ought to go a long way.

Some years ago I got a nice document from a vendor that does lightning/EMP mitigation for commercial transmitters and the like. I have a vivid memory of the attention to be paid to having straight runs of ground conductors, with no sharp turns, from the spark-gap, or other means to the ground system.

I had a lightning strike smoke a bunch of USB stuff and some RS-232 drivers in my telescope mount in my observatory. The mount, of course, was bolted to a steel pier on a big chunk of concrete in the ground. You could trace the path of destruction starting at the USB hub power brick, through the one of the two USB hub chips (the other 3 ports still worked!), the USB/serial adapters, RS-232 drivers and.. ground. I added a local ground rod and surge-supresser on the electric sub-panel that protected L1, L2 and neutral to ground. The sub-panel has the neutral isolated from ground per code.. and there's a 200 yard long buried run for lighting to induce surges into. What fun. https://www.flickr.com/phot...

posts.message:
Mark,

Honestly I hadn't even tried the built-in motion detection. I looked over the docs and configuration settings on it and decided there's no way it's going to be either accurate or configurable enough for me. The settings I'm using now for ZoneMinder are pretty detailed, and dialed in after a lot of testing in different conditions to figure out how much motion in what parts of the frame is worth notifying me about.

If you can get the motion detection working for you, that's fine. And honestly if all you're planning on doing is having it record to the Pi to use as evidence after-the-fact, that's probably perfectly workable. I am, however, using the cameras as part of my home security system - when I detect motion and my security system is armed, it immediately sends the frame to my phone and email as an "alarm" notification. So my main desire was to have motion detection with low-to-no false positives.

-Jason

posts.message: So the *perl* code triggers... at some point. It actually polls the shared memory every 3 seconds, so depending on the length of the event, it could trigger at the start, in the middle, or (for a very short event) at the end. The Python handler that my perl code is calling waits up to 30 seconds for the event to finish, so that would be possible.

posts.message: I find a good way to eliminate false positives from movement detection is to only trigger home automation/alarm responses for movement detection that continues for more than e.g. 10 seconds. Not sure that's compatible with this approach, as (unless I'm understanding), the pl code only triggers when the event starts - not when it ends...

posts.message:
Thanks, I'm glad you enjoyed the post. I saw quite a few people mention using PIR to trigger alerts/recording but (sadly ironic, in retrospect) I didn't want to purchase any more components.

:( I looked into Zigbee a few years ago, but it seems that Z-Wave currently has a pretty decent selection of alarm system components, so that's the way I went. If I'd followed through with my automation plans in the past, I'd probably also have existing assorted Zigbee devices.

Yeah, with anything wireless/radio there's always the possibility of interference (either intentional or accidental) causing issues. I really don't see myself or my neighborhood being targeted by the level of criminal that would intentionally de'auth a WiFi camera... but if that happens, I'll still get an alert from my monitoring about the loss of the camera/signal. I didn't go crazy with monitoring, but I have enough in place that I'll know rather quickly if someone disconnects or obstructs a camera, or for that matter cuts my Internet connection.

posts.message:
As with your last post, I've enjoyed reading this one, too. Interesting that you ended up with ZoneMinder after all, the object recognition does sound pretty cool. I've been able to cut down on the false positives by pairing a PIR with the Amcrest motion detection, only triggereing an action in Home Assistant when both are true, and using the iOS component to send a message to my iPhone. Hasn't totally eliminated false positives, though ...

Most of my assorted small devices are Zigbee rather than Zwave, more by chance than design. I found out the hard way that Zigbee devices don't talk to each other unless the profiles match, so my working devices are all ZHA v1.2, plus a small box of devices that don't work :-(

After buying my WiFi cameras, I discovered that a $5 device from ebay, which comes preprogrammed, can knock them offline through a deautherization attack. Unless your router supports 802.11w, which mine does not. Oh well.

posts.message:
Clifton,

As to multiple regions, since I wrote this post we've modified the above code to deploy into six regions of our main account (the six regions we actively use). The gist of the modifications was to replace all instances of the region name ("us-east-1" in the above code) with a placeholder string. We then copy our built policies and config files into six different directories, one per region, and replace the placeholder string with the appropriate region name in each of them. We then run custodian and our other tooling six times, once per region, pointing at the region-specific configuration directory. That seems to handle multi-region quite well, with the one caveat that we run exactly the same policies and configuration in each region.

Right now we haven't expanded that specific tooling into multiple accounts yet. The vast majority of our other accounts are small single-app accounts, and c7n is being managed by the team that manages the app, usually with whatever tooling is available and recommended by the community (so usually something that looks much more like a plain/vanilla custodian deployment).

We have discussed how we'd go about managing this same tooling across multiple accounts and I'll share our plans, but note we haven't implemented this yet and it's essentially just a whiteboard discussion:

1. Extract all configuration and account-specific pieces out of the current code and into configuration files (YAML, properties files, etc.)
2. Refactor that configuration into a separate git repository, so that we end up with one repo with the Jenkinsfile and deployment tooling, and another repo with the policies and config files specific to an account.
3. Add some global policies to the repo with the deployment tooling, and make sure that they properly merge in addition to the account-specific policies.
4. Scale out to more account-specific repos.

-Jason

posts.message:
Personally I'd be a little hesitant to make such drastic changes to VyOS... it might be based on Debian, but VyOS really is its own system, and seems to make some assumptions about how it will be set up. If you want to give it a try, go right ahead, but I'm not sure how it might fail or even if such failures will be immediately obvious from the outside. I do know, however, that you'd need to identify all of the locations that VyOS actually writes to disk.

In my opinion, doing something like this is just premature optimization with modern flash memory... if the card lasts 2-4 years, is that really an issue?

posts.message:
Thanks!

c7n manages the Lambdas itself - the `custodian` command deploys them, and `mugc.py` handles garbage collection. The same is true of c7n-mailer which uses Lambdas. In fact, to do all of the Lambda management cloud custodian includes a Python module, `mu.py`, that's actually an incredibly full-featured Lambda lifecycle management tool.

But I didn't include the terraform because of the extremely small set of resources it contains. The only things managed via terraform are:

* One IAM role for the Lambdas to run under (aws_iam_role), along with the policy for that role (aws_iam_role_policy).
* One S3 Bucket (aws_s3_bucket) per region, which custodian will write its output to
* One SQS Queue (aws_sqs_queue) in us-east-1 for the mailer Lambda. All policies are configured to use this queue for mailer notifications, and we provision the c7n-mailer function only in us-east-1 and reading from this queue.
* One SQS Queue (aws_sqs_queue) per region for our custom code to log to Splunk, which functions much the same as c7n-mailer.
* One SQS Queue (aws_sqs_queue) per region to act as the Lambda Dead Letter Queue for monitoring.

Since I posted this, we've started deploying into multiple regions using one set of configs, a placeholder value for the region name, and a bash script that runs sed to generate configs for each region. So ignoring multiple regions, the terraform is only 6 resources.

So to clarify, c7n itself (or c7n-mailer, etc.) manages all of the Lambdas. We were already using SES, so there's no configuration there. All Terraform is doing is managing the IAM, S3 and SQS stuff.

posts.message:
In terms of open source, I think I've heard of a few modern possibilities, aside from the old standards (e.g. using something like Puppet to distribute everyone's public keys to the servers, or cron to pull everyone's public keys, or using a bastion host with a captive account).

Vault is open source, though they offer a paid, supported Enterprise version as well. It's probably a bit of overkill just for SSH; it's intended to be a full "secret management" solution, i.e. authenticating users and machines and giving them (ACL'ed, leased, audited, time-limited) access to "secrets" that can be arbitrary strings or key/value pairs, as well as "dynamic" secrets (i.e. creating database users, IAM users, etc. on-demand and expiring them after a given amount of time, or revoking them on request). I'll admit that Vault is probably overkill for your needs; it's intended to be extremely secure and extremely reliable.

So the gist of Vault's SSH backend is that it operates in one of two modes; it can either generate random SSH keys and provision the private part onto a host, and give the public part to a user, or it can use a "one time password" method, where users are given a one-time-password (from Vault) to access a host, and then the host runs a script that verifies the password against Vault.

As to not having a need for SSH, my employer does that for a few of our projects. In my opinion, the practice is based on two premises: (1) immutable infrastructure, i.e. nothing is EVER changed on an instance, you run a deploy job that replaces the instances, and (2) your monitoring/logging/etc. *should* do everything you'd need to do via SSH on an instance, and if it doesn't, that's a problem that needs to be fixed. Another option that I've used (assuming you're using ephemeral instances, i.e. autoscaling) is that if something needs to be investigated on-instance, it's a matter of someone spinning up a new instance with SSH enabled (and their personal key, or a shared one), that gets killed off after a while.

posts.message:
Steve,

This solution was never fully implemented before I left the employer I was working on it for. As far as I know they never continued, due to rather sweeping management and technical changes. If I had to do it over again, I would almost certainly use HashiCorp Vault, which provides an SSH backend ( https://www.vaultproject.io... ) that can fill this use case, among many others. I'm using that now, but for things other than SSH access.

I can't think of the names offhand, but there are also a number of other projects in the same space that could handle this need, and have emerged in the last few years.

However, all of that being said... I think these days, the best solution is... don't allow SSH access. Or, if you do, make it rare and tightly controlled. In a modern world with log aggregation and immutable infrastructure, SSH-less machines are becoming quite a bit more common.

-Jason

posts.message:
Derek,

Firstly, this post was written when Terraform 0.6.something was out... the current version is 0.7.10, and a LOT of progress has been made since then, especially around data sources.

I know that you can now use the "template_file" data source to interpolate a template string, and that *may* help. However, for the most part, I'm always running Terraform with a wrapper script. We have an (internal only, for now) Rubygem that we use to wrap terraform, that generates Rake tasks to plan/apply/etc. a given terraform configuration, and also handles automatically setting up remote state storage, and writing specified environment and/or ruby variables into a "-var-file" JSON... so the overhead of using that for variables isn't too bad.

-Jason

Just a thought...

Thanks. Looking at the docs[1], might it be better to specify "NotAction": "Update:Modify" instead of "Action" : "Update:*" in the "Deny" rule that protects the database? posts.message:
Cameron,

It took me a bit - this post is *really* old - but the inspiration was a custom console (it's somewhere on this page: http://www.odysseyauto.com/... ) by Odyssey Specialty Vehicles in Wharton, NJ. I just used the photo of that to get the rough shape of the console I wanted. I then took an insane amount of measurements of the space, as well as the bolt pattern on the old factory console, and drew up plans. Once I thought the measurements were right, I cut the pieces out of foam core board (that stuff kids use for display boards in school - about 1/4" of hard foam sandwiched between heavy paper) and taped them together, then trimmed and re-cut as needed to get it to fit right, and used the foam core pieces as a template to cut the plywood.

-Jason

Thanks for the response! I appreciate how in-depth it is.

I agree with everything you've said, and you've given me a new way to think about RDS instances in stacks. The only reason I wanted to include them is because they rely on the VPC (including subnets, a bastion host for access, etc), and then application instances rely on RDS, so they are kind of in the middle of everything. Also, we sometimes make modifications to RDS security groups and parameter groups, and CF would help there too (maybe, or it would just try and destroy the instance...).

I'll have to take another look at Terraform. I've read about their architecture and I think it sounds great. I heard a few bad reviews from folks who have large and complex setups and they said there are too many race conditions and edge cases in terraform, but I'm sure like all good open-source software it improves over time.

Thanks so much for your help!

The only reason I wanted to include them is because they rely on the VPC (including subnets, a bastion host for access, etc), and then application instances rely on RDS, so they are kind of in the middle of everything. Also, we sometimes make modifications to RDS security groups and parameter groups, and CF would help there too (maybe, or it would just try and destroy the instance...).

I'll have to take another look at Terraform. I've read about their architecture and I think it sounds great. I heard a few bad reviews from folks who have large and complex setups and they said there are too many race conditions and edge cases in terraform, but I'm sure like all good open-source software it improves over time.

Thanks so much for your help!

posts.message:
Yes, it really doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me... and the inability to add existing resources to stacks has come up a few times for me as well, whether because of technical reasons or human error.

I actually changed jobs about 7 months ago, and at the new shop we're using a mix of a bunch of different deployment techniques depending on the application and team; I think we have CloudFormation, ElasticBeanstalk, Terraform, and a number of homegrown tools (and combinations like ElasticBeanstalk apps that also include a CloudFormation stack). Most of the stuff that I've been working with lately doesn't rely on RDBMS instances, so I can't say I've fought the CF/RDS fight recently. With most of the things I've seen others doing lately, I haven't seen a good CF solution beyond "stack policy to protect it, and backups."

All of that being said, I'm starting to converge on an idea that I've heard more and more lately both from colleagues and in blogs/presentations/etc.: AWS gives us basic building blocks. If you want to have a truly automated infrastructure, you're *going* to have to build on top of what AWS gives us. One example I hear more and more lately is people talking about using AutoScalingGroups, but controlling the scaling with their own tooling.

The other thing I've heard a lot of people discuss - and that really resonates with me in a way that wasn't originally clear - is that perhaps **data** resources (like RDS instances) simply shouldn't be part of a CF stack, because they really can't be torn down and re-deployed arbitrarily without the possibility of data loss.

If I looked at this at a high level, and assumed that I had the time and resources to do this, I'd say that the most Right solution I can think of (which may or may not already exist, probably as a product?) is some sort of orchestration service. I.e. a tool (whether scripts, a collection of Jenkins jobs or web tools, whatever) that handles all of your CloudFormation work and can:

1. detect that a DB is going to be replaced
2. take the application offline, and/or ensure that all processing is complete
3. snapshot (or just back up, i.e. outside of AWS's builtin snapshots) the RDS instance
4. run the CF that replaces the RDS instance, but have the app start in an offline mode
5. restore the DB backup/snapshot
6. let traffic flow to the app

So after all that, I really question if having RDS instances as part of the app CF stack makes sense. I think my gut reaction is, at least for apps that aren't trivial or very rarely changed, that nothing which can't be trivially destroyed and replaced should be part of the CF stack. We might try and make RDS work like some magic EC2 instance, but it's not; it's a persistent resource with requirements far different from stateless components, and it needs to be managed separately.

For what it's worth, my own team has been using mostly HashiCorp Terraform ( https://www.terraform.io/ ) for deployment lately. It's provider-agnostic, so you can deploy to AWS, Google Cloud, OpenStack, etc. (the resources are distinct; there's an EC2 instance, not a generic compute resource, but you can also mix providers in one configuration) and also has provisioning capabilities (file provisioning and local or remote execs, plus builtin support for things like users and DBs in Postgres or MySQL).

One major feature of Terraform is the ability to preview all changes before applying them (this seems to have just been introduced in CF with "change sets" - https://aws.amazon.com/blog... ). I haven't done anything with trying to extend Terraform yet, but I was considering the possibility of hooking in custom code for things like DB backup/restore...

Excellent blog post, thanks! I'm currently trying to migrate from Ansible provisioning to CloudFormation, and by far the biggest blocker is how CloudFormation handles RDS instances. Some of the decisions they made regarding how RDS instances are updated are really nonsensical. I also wish you could add an existing RDS instance to a stack instead of having to create a new instance from a snapshot.

Have you had trouble dealing with CloudFormation and RDS since you wrote this blog post? Do you wish you handled your RDS instances another way besides using CloudFormation?

posts.message:
The environment variables in the apache configuration files, (i.e. ${HTTP_ENV_NAME}) are defined in the apache/httpd service's configuration file. On RedHat-based systems, this is /etc/sysconfig/httpd and it would contain the variable you want to set, i.e. "HTTP_ENV_NAME=something" where "something" is the name of your environment.

How you get them in that file is up to you. Assuming you use some sort of configuration management (which you should; Puppet, Chef, Ansible, Salt, whatever), that should handle populating the variable with the correct environment name, as it should know the proper environment name. If you're not already using some sort of configuration management for your services, I'd highly recommend that you do.

posts.message:
So far, we haven't tried this. Off the top of my head, I think everything we have falls into one of the following three categories:

(1) RDS, where as far as I can tell, the endpoint isn't supposed to change even if a node is replaced.
(2) ElastiCache memcached, where we use the Amazon Configuration Endpoint.
(3) Other stuff (like ElastiCache Redis) where we just pass the cluster id into the application, and the app queries for the connection info.

The majority of our applications aren't long-lived - they're either web apps or batch transaction processing - so reconnection should be tried pretty regularly.

Aside from that, we currently don't do anything for config reloads. This might be a problem in the long-term, but we haven't had any issues with it so far. In the rare case that we do have an issue, we just kill off instances and let them autoscale back.

One day I was working on a python project, I use TDD so I rarely check my results on a screen, according to my wakatime I spent 11 hours coding. Yesterday though I started hammering at 11 (had a long meeting in the morning) but I was working on javascript, and my unit testing in js is NULL, so according to my wakatime I only coded for 6 hours, even though I left the office at 7, meaning I wasted almost three hours checking my results visually (minus going for a soda and back). While I don't want to share this info with anyone, it does help me realize I need to step tests game up in js.

I tend to focus all my OCD, all my obsessions, and all my nit picking, into building stuff, and I hate those companies that track the actual coding time because I've seen the managers do SHIT. If one person of the higher ups, can waste all his day using outlook and meetings, then by that same measure everyone is entitled to do shit, it's just that there are some great people out there that actually use their time to do valuable and quantifiable work.

So yeah this tool is fantastic, because I haven't worked at all on my personal projects in months.

posts.message:
Rohitt,

This is a **very** old post - maybe so much so that it should be deleted. Yes, I did find something like this. Puppet. Seven years ago it may not have been the right solution, but today I completely feel that Puppet (or one of the other, similar configuration management systems) is. In fact, that's exactly what I use to manage my personal desktop computer and my work-provided laptop - see https://github.com/jantman/...

For stuff other than desktop and laptop - like, anything that could fall into the "server" category - configuration management is THE solution. And not just that, but with the ease of using virtualization and container technology, there's really no reason not to just rebuild the whole machine every few days/weeks/months.

-Jason

posts.message:
> Unfortunately, rspec doesn’t have a nice, clean way to make assertions about a hash item.

In RSpec 3, we do actually have a nice, clean way to do this: composable matchers:

http://rspec.info/blog/2014...

In a nutshell, composable matchers allow you to pass matchers as arguments to other matchers. In fact, it uses Ruby's `===` protocol so you can use any object that implements that protocol (such as a regex). Your example could be written like this in RSpec 3:

``` ruby
describe http_get(80, 'testapp1.jasonantman.com', '/testapp1234') do
its(:headers) { should include('server' => /nginx\/1\./) }
end
```

Composable matchers are a lot more flexible than just supporting a regex, though; you could, for example, use `a_string_string_with` (an alias of the `start_with` matcher) for this case:

``` ruby
describe http_get(80, 'testapp1.jasonantman.com', '/testapp1234') do
its(:headers) { should include('server' => a_string_starting_with("nginx/1")) }
end
```

You can also use matchers at _any_ level in a nested data structure, so I think what RSpec has built-in now is considerably more flexible than `have_hash_item_matching`.

posts.message:
As I said above about DeletionPolicy:

"Be warned, this only takes effect when you
delete the entire stack. If you make a change to one of the DBInstance properties
that requires a resource replacement to
take effect, the RDS instance will be replaced with a new one, and all of the data and automatic snapshots from the old one will be deleted.
That last part deserves repeating: automatic snapshots (the daily ones created by RDS) are tied to the instance; if the instance is replaced
by CloudFormation, you lose all automatic (backup) snapshots with it."

DeletionPolicy only takes effect when the resource is explicitly deleted by an API call. When CloudFormation *replaces* a resource because of a parameter change that requires replacement (such as changing the master username or password on an RDS instance), the DeletionPolicy is **not triggered**.

Also keep in mind that even if this worked logically - DeletionPolicy properly creating the snapshot when the RDS instance is replaced - you'd still end up with a broken application until you restored the snapshot (which would require *another* RDS instance to be spun up, as snapshots can't be restored to running instances).

(3) Logging is your friend - it might be worth replacing these hook scripts with ones that log their input somewhere so you can debug it.

-Jason

Tony, the usual rules for variable "scoping" apply in the sysconfig files. You need:

export HTTPD_ONLINE="mod"

Without using "export", the new environment variable won't be passed to the execution environment of new processes. Sorry for the confusion, I'll update this.

posts.message:
Resurrecting an ooollldddd post, because I like to!

FYI: there's a much easier way of doing this.

Once you get a root prompt, either through the creative process above, or booting into single user mode:

Edit /etc/sudoers and change the %admin line to something like this:
%admin ALL = NOPASSWD: ALL
:wq!

At this point, you should have a very handy root for any user in the admin group (beware, 'id' does not report alternate groups ...), but everytime you reboot, you'll lose this config! 'saveconf' doesn't save this file.

Here's the trick:

Edit /etc/config_files and add /etc/sudoers, then run saveconf again.

Works for me, YMMV, don't blow up your stuff, not responsible, etc etc.
posts.raw_message:
Resurrecting an ooollldddd post, because I like to!

FYI: there's a much easier way of doing this.

Once you get a root prompt, either through the creative process above, or booting into single user mode:

Edit /etc/sudoers and change the %admin line to something like this:
%admin ALL = NOPASSWD: ALL
:wq!

At this point, you should have a very handy root for any user in the admin group (beware, 'id' does not report alternate groups ...), but everytime you reboot, you'll lose this config!  'saveconf' doesn't save this file.

Here's the trick:

Edit /etc/config_files and add /etc/sudoers, then run saveconf again.

Works for me, YMMV, don't blow up your stuff, not responsible, etc etc.

posts.message:
Here's a list of some tests to run through when writing new init scripts:

Status Tests:
while running (exit 0):
stopped, pid file exists (exit 1):
stopped, lock file exists (exit 2):
stopped, pid and lock gone (exit 3):

Action Tests:

starting when stopped (should create pidfile and lockfile, exit 0):
starting when stopped, with pidfile (should work normally, overwrite pidfile):
starting when stopped with lockfile (should fail and exit 1):
starting when running (should exit 0, do nothing else):

stopping when running (exit 0, remove pidfile and lockfile):
stopping when stopped (exit 0, do nothing else):

restart when running (exit 0, update pidfile):
restart when stopped (exit 0, restart, create lockfile and pidfile):

condrestart when running (exit 0, update pidfile):
condrestart when stopped (should exit 0, do nothing):

reload (unimplemented, should exit 3):

force-reload (unimplemented, should exit 3):

start as non-root user (no privs, should exit 4):

posts.message:
Yes, Puppetlabs' development of Dashboard has stopped. The announcement said that they (PuppetLabs) would be replacing the functionality with a combination of open source applications (PuppetDB to store reports and facts and present them via an API, and apparently will eventually include some basic report viewing; and a new, not-yet-seen ENC as a separate application) and a web UI to these services as a proprietary application (I assume a replacement for the current Puppet Enterprise Console).

My understanding from Nigel Kersten's email re: The Future of Puppet Dashboard (2012-10-10) was that they were open to someone picking up maintenance of Dashboard as an open source project, but I'm unaware of what happened with this.

I'll probably update this post sometime soon, as not only has the landscape changed somewhat, but I'm also actively involved in a soon-to-be-open-source ENC written by a coworker.

posts.message:
Daniel,

That's not what this filter is doing. "ether host" matches on the Ethernet frame header, which at the very least will be incorrect in an environment using a DHCP relay, such as a routed environment using Cisco's "ip helper" to forward DHCP between subnets. But more importantly, it bears no direct relation to DHCP. A DHCP server identifies the client's MAC address by the CHADDR (Client Hardware Address) field of the DHCP packet header, not by the source address of the Ethernet frame. For more info, you can see the DHCP message format diagram, Figure 1 of RFC 2131: http://tools.ietf.org/html/...

"udp[38:4]" matches the CHADDR field of the DHCP packet, which should be what the DHCP server "sees" as the client hardware address, regardless of the network topology or the lower layers (UDP, IP, Ethernet) of the packet.

I would say you'd stick to Logstash with Kibana (especially with Kibana, as Logstash is easily replacable with Fluentd, what I am doing actually). Logstash, as far as I know, transports generalized messages (think of JSON), causing pretty much the same result as Graylog2.

> Graylog2 – a centralized log management application with a powerful web interface

Its web interface is poor. It can't do much analytics (just two or three hardcoded, you can only select entries to analyse). It doesn't have sensible dashboard. The thing is only useful for searching and for setting up alerting on when anything matching some criteria comes, but even these two are quite limited.

I don't see why people get so delighted by Graylog2.

Sathyam,

Yes, you have two troubleshooting tools; one is the SSH logso n your server to make sure it’s at least connecting, and the other, if you long-press each profile in the Rsync Backup app and select “Edit”, near the bottom of the screen is a check box “Close log window after job is done.” If you uncheck this, save the profile, and then tap the profile once to run it, you’ll be able to see the output of the rsync process on your phone. If you can paste that here, I might be able to give you a hint at what the problem is.

-Jason

posts.message: We have a Hubmax II that was installed about 10 years ago. We have over 200 users. The controller stopped communicating with the PC that we had connected with an RS-232 connection. Attempts to connect locally using the proprietary local connection cable doesn't work, either. We used to use dialup to remotely manage the system, but after replacing 2 modems because of surges coming from the telco connection, we stopped dialing in. We are running out of new, unissued prox cards, with no way to add/remove any users. We have also tried to manage the system through the keypad on the first controller module, but also doesn't seem to respond. We are thinking about replacing the entire controller board, and/or the first module.

posts.message:
Martijn,

Thanks for the comment. Since I posted this, I've started doing some serious testing of Foreman. I'll admit the docs are a bit unclear - you need a smart-proxy to communicate with the puppetmaster, even if they're on the same host. I've been spending quite a bit of time on it, and I've found a few bugs (and even patched two minor ones). The biggest surprise was that if you want it to work with new-ish puppet (2.6.x+) you really need to run the "develop" branch of Foreman. That all being said, it's a lot closer to what my company needs than Dashboard, so I think I'm going to test all I can and consider learning Ruby and contributing whatever is missing that we need most.

Good luck with your experiments!

posts.message:
I'm investigating the same things currently. As I'm pretty new to Puppet, but am dying to get some config management onto our systems, I've set up Puppet Dashboard for reporting and as an ENC. It was reasonably simple to get working, although it helps a lot if you've deployed Rails apps before.

The Foreman seems to have a lot more features, and installing it via the Debian package was easier than with Dashboard. However, actually connecting it to the Puppet Master wasn't so easy. The documentation is lacking and I gave up after several hours. For now Dashboard will be sufficient for my needs.

It may still be interesting to have a look at Foreman though, since it seems it's possible to integrate with existing DHCP and DNS servers via the Foreman smart-proxy (http://theforeman.org/proje.... I don't know how well it works, but this may be what you were looking for too.
posts.raw_message:
I'm investigating the same things currently. As I'm pretty new to Puppet, but am dying to get some config management onto our systems, I've set up Puppet Dashboard for reporting and as an ENC. It was reasonably simple to get working, although it helps a lot if you've deployed Rails apps before.

The Foreman seems to have a lot more features, and installing it via the Debian package was easier than with Dashboard. However, actually connecting it to the Puppet Master wasn't so easy. The documentation is lacking and I gave up after several hours. For now Dashboard will be sufficient for my needs.

It may still be interesting to have a look at Foreman though, since it seems it's possible to integrate with existing DHCP and DNS servers via the Foreman smart-proxy (http://theforeman.org/projects/smart-proxy/wiki). I don't know how well it works, but this may be what you were looking for too.

Well, I found the answer to that questions. The build ID is only needed if you wish to build the debuginfo package, and I don't. So I added this to the top of the spec file:

%define debug_package %{nil}
posts.raw_message: Well, I found the answer to that questions. The build ID is only needed if you wish to build the debuginfo package, and I don't. So I added this to the top of the spec file: %define debug_package %{nil}

Thanks. I haven't tried syncing locally but, then again, I'm perfectly happy to for the first time have all of my contacts synced between all of my computers. There may be some way to prevent contact syncing, or perhaps use an alternate email app that keeps its' own address book.

As to calendar, with the builtin apps, you essentially have the choice between using Google Calendar or having the calendar app subscribe to a web-accessible calendar.

There are probably ways to accomplish what you want, but it likely involves replacing the Google Mail, Calendar, etc. apps with alternatives.

posts.message:
I never said that they didn't have the right to do it - I read my EULA. I never even said that they shouldn't be able to do it - however it does open up a lot of thoughts about their technical capabilities (how easily would they monitor/record my viewing habits without making it more explicit than the size 6 print?)

The real issues are two-fold: First, most of their (non-technical) customers probably don't realize the amount of control they actually have over the set-top boxes. Secondly, on the practical side, the only thing this will really do is upset customers - I already heard enough of their advertising about the ABC thing on the radio and on regular TV ads, it just pushes it one step further when I have to see it every time I turn on my TV.

posts.message:
OK, I just got this printer and had the same issues with DHCP. After trawling the net I found this solution that worked for me.

1. Power of the printer.
2. With the "go" button (big blue button) pressed down, power the printer back on. Keep the button pressed until all the Toner, Drum and Error lights come on. Release the button.
3. Now press the button 10 times.
4. Wait for the "go" button to come on again and then press it 3 times to print a test page.

The manual said to press the button 7 times to go back to factory defaults, but I read an article (http://www.brother-usa.com/... about configuring the printer with out a cable attached and it said 10 times. I tried 7 times method a few times and it never worked.

Let me know how you get on.

posts.message:
John,

Personally, I used APCupsd, mainly because I have that working for some of my older serial-based UPSs. I used its' SNMP check function, which does rely on the network being up. The other common *nix program is NUT, though it looks like the current version has only experimental support for SNMP.

At this point, I've never actually tested the shutdown. My UPSs will run for 23-29 minutes, and the only time I've had a power outage longer than that (since I've had these UPSs), I was on-site and able to manually shut down the machines (tree down, I knew it would be a long outage).

I also monitor over SNMP with Nagios.

-Jason

posts.message:
There's a broad range of functionality that falls under the umbrella of monitoring, and there's no one tool that does everything well.

At the BayLISA Monitoring SIG, which GroundWork Open Source hosts, we debated for a couple of meetings about what were the "core" monitoring functions, and we came up with the acronym GCAP which stands for:

Generation
Collection
Analysis
Presentation

Some monitoring tools do more than one of these well, but at the Monitoring SIG we concluded there's no one tool that is the best at them all.

That's why GroundWork Monitor has a framework architecture where presentation (i.e. graphing) tools like MRTG and Cacti can be interchanged but still interoperate. Yes, we've pre-loaded it with what we consider, based on our experience, to be the "best-of-breed" spanning GCAP and providing full coverage of monitoring functionality, but we allow you to swap our choice out with yours.

posts.message:
Jeff, thanks for the heads-up. I always appreciate the point of view of an insider.

Nagios works for me, but I do have some issues with it. One is the lack of features other than monitoring (why do I need to install Nagios *and* Munin or Cacti???). The other is the lack of ticketing, though I use Eventum, so I'd assume that most products don't have out-of-the-box support.

Another issue is the use - I first started running Nagios at home to monitor this site and the rest of my servers, so it's a relatively small installation (17 hosts, 165 services right now). I look at my home installation more as a testbed for stuff that I might implement for consulting clients, so it's always a plus to play around with different alternatives.

Of the alternatives I looked at, OpenNMS is definitely #1 (though at a casual glance it might be a tie). When I get around to it, I have a spare box running Xen that isn't doing much, maybe I'll give OpenNMS a shot in a test deployment.

Thanks for the feedback, and thanks for the work from all of you guys at OpenNMS.

posts.message:
If Nagios is what you know, and if it has worked for you in similar environments before, then there's no compelling reason to choose anything different. Network management is hard, and you shouldn't go making it harder just because you'd like something prettier :)

The issues that I see repeatedly with Nagios users are that they hit a scalability wall, or they want a solution that includes performance management, reactive fault management (e.g. proper SNMP trap support), event reduction, and trouble ticket system integration, without having to bolt these things to the side. If and when you find yourself thinking these thoughts, you should give OpenNMS a hard look. Because we get so many Nagios converts, we've made it easy to leverage existing deployments of NRPE and NSClient.

Regarding any product that comes in an Enterprise or Professional edition that has more features than the open source edition -- most of these vendors have taken on multiple rounds of VC, which means they can no longer exist without a software license revenue stream. It may be that one of these products will fit your needs, but be sure that you understand the potential monetary costs before you start going beyond the feature set available in the community version. Also be aware that support for these products may be sold separately from the right-to-use, and that the cost of support may increase as you grow your managed footprint. Contrast this to my employer, which thinks of itself as a steward of OpenNMS and makes money only on support, services, and training, all simply and reasonably priced.

-jeff

posts.message: Unless you're looking for something very esoteric, you should be able to have your cake and eat it too by going with GroundWork. Nagios is one of the many open source components unified into it, and it provides a GUI and integration with Cacti and other extensions. And you can always go back to stand-alone Nagios if you want.

posts.message:
John,

I did just take a look at Hyperic. I've heard a lot about it, and I'll admit, it does look good. I especially like the ability to trend min/max/average values for a metric and adjust thresholds accordingly. It's also got a nice interface (though it was painful for me to view the screenshots - being a fan of having a million tabs open, I prefer straight links to images). My one issue with it is that it's a J2EE app running on JBoss Application Server. While J2EE is a wonderful technology (shameless Sun plug), I really prefer something running as PHP or CGI with a MySQL backend - but just an issue of personal preference and hardware resources.

-J

posts.message:
Hello Jason,

get a Ultra 1/2/5/10 or 10 (these use the same type of NVRAM 48T59). Insert the NVRAM/IDPROM from the Blade 150 into one of these systems and use the procedure from the NVRAM-FAQ to re-program the IDPROM.
If you had written down the Ethernet address and Host ID from the first power-up of the Blades, you can even use the real ethernet address (only the last 3 byte of the ethernet address are on the yellow sticker, the first 3 differ). The HOST ID of the Blade 150 starts with 83.
For further questions re-use you post on forum.java.sun.com.

Michael

In a follow-up, I now have two backup clients working perfectly. The storage machine which was giving me RPM dependency problems is now totally f***ed. I attempted an online update, and that somehow upgraded glibc without worrying about the programs that depend on it, and now the machine is effectively bricked. I guess it's time for a new OS install. My longest-running machine will also suffer a problem, so I may just backup that box via NFS to something else, so I don't get forced into an upgrade sooner than I want.

I'm also looking into a web GUI...

posts.message: Nice work Jason - thanks. I'm also running OpenSuse 10.2 on a G1. I have now managed to get the full psp 7.8 SLES10 package loaded. This involves editing the Suse-release file found in /etc/ to make the script think its a SLES10. The script seems flaky and does not terminate correctly, but all the tools load ok. I've even managed to get the HP System Management Homepage running ok.

posts.message:
As a couunterpoint to your discussion, how about being on the opposite side of the spectrum?

I have to wonder how many people are actually in the same boat that I am - loads of experience with a vast array of systems, a low level degree (AAS in Computer Science) and a couple of widely recognized certifications - that don't get looked at by a lot of HR folks simply because they don't have a BS degree in Computer Science.

It just seems to me that the people who are actually hiring for positions in the IT field don't have the first clue about the IT field. They look for buzz words, figure that they need someone with a BS degree (no matter what that degree is in) and then ask for loads of experience. Doesn't matter if you truly have the skill set to do the job, as long as you've got the right paperwork.

I recall seeing an advertisement a number of years ago (roughly 2002), looking for a Windows 2000 Systems Administrator with 5+ years of experience. Gave me a good chuckle and a long pause, in that there was no way anyone could have 5+ years of experience with a product that had only come out 2 years prior and that there were actually people out there in a hiring role that were that clueless.

My best advice at this point, figure out what you enjoy doing, look at the skill set that you develop doing it and focus in that area. Don't forget that there are other areas in the IT field, but having one area that you shine in and others that you are familiar/comfortable with can really help.

posts.message:
As much as this seems to be an advertisement, I'm all for the service. And someone actually found my blog.

Personally, I use dynDns.org, but just because they're the first one I found so many years ago.

The question is how this would work with filters that filter by IP. As far as I can tell, it would have to be some sort of proxy setup (caching wouldn't work) where, from the viewpoint of the requester, the site came from the redirection domain on port 80, not port 10011 of the actual host.
